Translated from Wikipedia in Spanish:

“The Temple of Debod was a gift from Egypt to Spain in 1968 in compensation for Spanish aid after the international appeal made by Unesco to save the temples of Nubia, mainly Abu Simbel, in danger of disappearing due to the construction of the Aswan Dam.

In gratitude, Egypt donated four monuments to countries that responded to this claim in a significant way: Dendur to the United States (it is currently in the Metropolitan Museum in New York), Ellesiya to Italy (Egyptian Museum in Turin), Taffa to the Netherlands (Rijksmuseum van Oudheden in Leiden) and Debod to Spain.”

Why is the Temple of Debod named so?

The Temple of Debod, dedicated to the Gods Amun and Isis, once stood in the Nile Valley near Aswan in Egypt at a place called Debod, Depod or Dabud (there are various ways of spelling). In the 1970s when the Aswan Reservoir was built, the temple was moved to Spain. Today it is situated in the Parque del Oeste near the Royal Palace in Madrid.

What is it like living in Madrid?

Like every city Madrid has pros and cons. Personally I wouldn’t live anywhere else, but I understand some people might not like it.

Madrid has received immigrants from every part of Spain and it is a quintessential Spanish city (they say it’s harder to find a true madrileño from generations back than a needle in a haystack). It has also received immigrants from about everywhere in the world in the recent decades and some areas have become very multicultural.

Madrid is busy. It’s a big, bustling city. People love to be outdoors and it’s crowded with locals and tourists, specially in the shopping areas. There’s a bar on every corner and they are lively and loud. Socializing is easy and the nightlife is never ending.

It’s a very open and tolerant city that welcomes everyone, it has a very active LGTB+ scene, and has very varied areas, from posh to hip to alternative to traditional middle-class, so there’s always something for everyone. It has a wide cultural offer with world class museums, theatres, opera, musicals, concerts and festivals, jazz and flamenco clubs. Public transportation is cheap and excellent, and there’s many parks for outdoor activity.

But did I say it’s busy? And crowded and noisy? It’s cold in winter and very hot and stuffy in summer (we’re having a mild summer with 35ºC/95ºF). Housing is expensive compared to the salaries people earn, and the job market is still recovering from the financial crisis. The whole center of the city is being increasingly gentrified and touristified and literally roaming with people. And it’s very Spanish: friendly, but loud and with little personal space.

So if your ideal is Northern European order and tidiness it might not be your city. But I f you speak some Spanish, can have a good job, and like a more relaxed attitude about life you might love it.

How old is the Royal Palace of Madrid?

The current Palacio was constructed between 1738-1755. However, there has been a a royal building on the site since the 9th Century when the Moors built an outpost on the site overlooking the vega.

They say the Temple of Debod is one of the tourist attractions of Madrid. Who built it?

It had many builders.

The Temple of Debod is an Egyptian temple, it was gifted to Spain during Franco's dictatorship by the Egyptians, as a sign of gratitude for Spanish help at the time preserving other temples in the area of southern Egypt.

Basically Egypt sent one to Madrid for the aid preserving the others. So, as you can guess, its builders were not exactly related to Spain, except for one, ironically the last person to make additions to the temple was born in Spain (long before Franco).

The temple was built to the god Amon by the Nubian pharaoh Adikhalamani, the temple itself has inscriptions of him inside. It was during the Hellenistic period of Egypt north under the Ptolomys, and in fact later the temple was annexed and expanded by the Egyptians (Ptolomy VI).

Its last period was when it lied on the southern border of the Roman province of Egypt, with its last additions right after that under Octavian, and possible ones under emperor Hadrian (who was the one born in Spain long before Franco).

Now it is located in Parque de la Montaña (on maps), every single Madrilenian calls it Parque de Debod. Which consists of the big square with the temple, located right on top of a hill, and all the gardens around the temple expanding pretty much all the hill top.

To the north-east of the temple is Spain Square, just crossing Ferraz Street you have it, in fact you can see all the square from the temple. To the south-west of the temple you have a steep down-hill with gardens and some houses to Príncipe Pío Station and the Angel Gate, then the Manzanares River. To the east of the temple you have San Vicente Slope, which is a wide slope running between Debod hill and the palace hill. And finally, to the west of the temple, you have the West Park spanning the entire long hillside north-wards until Moncloa Palace.

The temple has become a place for couples to hang out, take pictures, have a picnic and spend the afternoon or evening making out. It's like everything that there is up there, that and large meet-ups in general, because other busy places are not that good for very large groups, and other parks like El Retiro are very large.

Does Madrid have a castle?

Depends on what you mean by Madrid and by castle.

There is the city of Madrid and the region of Madrid. The region of Madrid has a lot of castles in the towns around the city, which is quite funny to see, modern family suburbs with a castle standing in the middle. But the city itself doesn't have a castle, Madrid city has some 30 palaces (and another dozen in the surroundings), but they aren't castles… they are palaces.

Habsburg Madrid, see Oriente Palace in the back

Some of them were castles in the Middle Ages, but the owners reformed them into palaces as society changed and their defensive purpose became obsolete. In fact the castles that remain as such in the towns outside Madrid are all turned into museums.

Some of the castles in the towns/suburbs near Madrid…

Manzanares El Real, located in the town named after the river

Villaviciosa de Odón, in this castle died Ferdinand VI while he was on a casual stay there

San José de Valderas, these are the castles of the Marchis of Valderas located in Alcorcón

Torreón de Arroyomolinos, which belonged to Gonzalo Chacón, right hand of queen Isabella

Torreón de Éboli, the tower of the (in)famous Princess of Éboli, located in Pinto

Castillo de Torremocha, in Torremocha

La Coracera, in San Martín de Valdeiglesias on the mountains south-west

Castillo de Chinchón, belonged to the Counts of Chinchón, obviously in the town of Chinchón

What is your favorite historical building in Madrid?

My preferred building is the Edificio Carrión, also called Edificio Capitol. This building which contains the Capitol Cinema was finished in 1933. Edificio Capitol is a good sample of the expressionist architecture having many details of ‘Art Deco’ in its decoration. It is an icon of the Gran Vía, a say ‘modern street’ of Madrid that soon will see its 100th anniversary.

Madrid has a problem or a virtue, it does not sell itself, there is no big landmark or big icon of the city to take pictures and put on repetitive expensive shirts of “I love…”. If you want that in Spain, Barcelona will do (and I absolutely love Barcelona, don't get me wrong).

Madrid's beauty is in the simple and daily, Castilian character is mostly austere, traditionally has been that way, they made the Baroque austere so imagine! (And I say they because back then my family was Galician, not Castilian). Castilian architecture is always small, modest, it doesn't mean less beautiful, but let's say if the Eiffel Tower were in Madrid it would be a 3rd of its size at best. Don't believe me? This is what we made with the icon of the city:

It is the size of a person, if it were French, it would be the size of 5 Napoleons the least and the pomp would be all over it with golden apples or something. But the people of Madrid like it simple, smaller, closer to the floor. The square is beautiful, the buildings, the statue, even the light… but it is clearly austere and modest.

This is the character of Madrid, almost ashamed of showing off, but it is quite beautiful, don't believe me? I'll make competence to Alejandro this time and give you a glance:

And of course, Madrid's art…

Prado Museum…

Pablo Picasso…

Francisco de Goya…

Diego de Velázquez…

Madrid is low key beautiful, not out loud presumptuous.

It is clearly Mediterranean architecture sinilar to other cities in Spain or Italy (colours, façade, decoration, Catholic motives…) with some French Art Déco touch here and there from the Bourbons and Austrian/Alpine black pointy rooftops from the Habsburgs; Madrid was the city of the royals so the French and Austrian touch is far stronger in Madrid than any other Spanish city. Terraces, museums, squares, fountains and statues, lots of fountains and lots of statues all over the city, all the detail and art in the city is in the endless number of fountains and statues (apart from the museums of course), not in big constructions like in many other cities.

What is it like to live in Madrid? The daily life, food, jobs, business, night life, people, how's it to live there?

I recently moved to Madrid from the UK. It’s my first time living overseas. I don’t speak the language. I came here with my wife and young daughter. Here are my observations:

  1. It’s hot. Really hot. From about May until October, there’s a prolonged period of dry, hot weather. Temperatures can get up into the 40ºC levels. And because there’s no nearby sea, don’t expect it to cool down a whole lot in the evenings / night times.
  2. The city functions on its stomach. Whatever the time of day, Madrileños (people from Madrid) are to be found sitting on terraces and in cafés eating and drinking (see #4).
  3. Folks work long hours. The working day starts by 9am, and generally doesn’t finish until 6:30pm. Shops stay open later into the evening too.

    However, at the height of summer the city goes into a kind of extended siesta, where working hours are significantly reduced, many businesses close down completely, and about half the city runs away to somewhere with a cooler breeze and more water.
  4. Mealtimes take some getting used to.

    As far as I can make out, there are about 5 general meal ‘zones’ -

    early breakfast - when you wake up you drink a coffee and maybe eat some fruit or something

    late breakfast - between 10am and 12pm you have another coffee and grab a snack like a churros (basically a cylindrical donut), a tostada (two halves of a small baguette or similar, toasted with jam or tomatoes) or a croissant

    lunch - between 1.30pm and 4pm you’ll have a large-ish meal - none of this eating-a-sandwich-at-your-desk nonsense

    tapas - from when you leave work until about 9pm you’ll often head to a local bar for a cold drink and a (normally complimentary) small snack - something like jamon (cured ham), olives, croquetas (fried balls of béchamel with various flavourings) , tortilla de patatas (thick potato omelette) etc

    dinner - any time from 8pm - 12pm people will sit down for their evening meal, which can be large or light
  5. The most important things to Madrileños seem to be:
    1. Family
    2. Friends
    3. Food & drink
    4. Football
  6. You’re living in a community. For better and for worse. Unlike the rather reserved, prim and proper manner of people back home in the UK, in Madrid (and perhaps in Spain generally) everybody’s business is everybody else’s.

    This means that people are really helpful, caring and generous with their time and energy. When I first moved here, colleagues would arrive at our new apartment unannounced (I still have no idea how they got the address) with little treats like wine and snacks. Anyone we meet who catches that we’re new in town immediately offers advice on where to go, what to see, and what’s best to eat.

    There’s a downside too. Sometimes the advice is not needed, or even a little antagonising to our Anglo-Saxon ears (like the times old ladies comment loudly in the street to my wife that our daughter ‘must be cold only wearing one layer’ - they mean well, but it comes across as judgey). The Spanish, like many continental Europeans, are bluntly honest. If they think you’re wrong, they override you, correct you, or tell you what you should be doing instead. You have to learn to ride along with it.
  7. The bureaucracy sucks. Getting a bank account, registering for an ‘NIE number’ (a tax code that is totally essential and virtually impossible to get), getting a doctor…these tasks can be frustrating. Primarily because of #8.
  8. People don’t speak a whole lot of English. So, learn some key phrases. In general, if you ask ‘habla usted Inglés?’ you’ll get a shrug of the shoulders or a shake of the head. From that point on, you’re going to either need a little Spanish, or have to rely on pointing / gesturing and smiling a lot.
  9. They love children. If you’re moving here with your kids, then you will feel very pleased that you did.

    Everywhere we go, our daughter gets her cheeks pinched, hair ruffled, offered sweets, sometimes even picked up or her hand held. Don’t be put off or nervous (unless the character in question is suspicious or dangerous looking). In general, and thinking back to point #6, folks here are a lot more open and sharing than you might be used to.
  10. It’s a wonderful place and we love it. Madrid has a little something for everyone - beautiful parks, quaint old streets, uncountable terraces, bars, restaurants, nightclubs and cafés, interesting cultural attractions, unique and distinctive neighbourhoods with diverse characters. It’s a great city.

How did Madrid, Spain get its name?

As Isaac Riquelme says it most recently comes from the Arab Magrit or Magerit, though there seems to be evidence of a former small Roman or Visigoth settlement called Matrice. There might have been other previous names so there’s actually several theories.

Both names seem to be related to streams or water but there doesn’t seem to be a consensus among linguists from what I’ve read. Although the river Manzanares is relatively small Madrid had many other waterways that have been covered by the city, and also many underground streams.

The old motto of Madrid was “fui sobre agua edificada, mis muros

As Isaac Riquelme says it most recently comes from the Arab Magrit or Magerit, though there seems to be evidence of a former small Roman or Visigoth settlement called Matrice. There might have been other previous names so there’s actually several theories.

Both names seem to be related to streams or water but there doesn’t seem to be a consensus among linguists from what I’ve read. Although the river Manzanares is relatively small Madrid had many other waterways that have been covered by the city, and also many underground streams.

The old motto of Madrid was “fui sobre agua edificada, mis muros de fuego son” (“I was built on top of water, my walls are made of fire”), referring to the underground streams, and apparently the fact that the walls were built with silex or flint and would spark when hit by enemy arrows.

Is Madrid a safe city?

Very safe by European standards, which is the same as saying one of the safest cities in the world.

If you're talking about crime in general, violent crime rates are very low and murders are almost unheard of. The following are official figures from the Interior Ministry:


For reference, the official population of Madrid (city only, not metropolitan area) is about 3.1 million, so the murder rate per 100k inhabitants is more or less 0.5. The city of Chicago, with slightly less population (2.7 million) has a murder rate 30 times higher (Crime in Chicago). Ok, maybe not a good example. The city of

Very safe by European standards, which is the same as saying one of the safest cities in the world.

If you're talking about crime in general, violent crime rates are very low and murders are almost unheard of. The following are official figures from the Interior Ministry:


For reference, the official population of Madrid (city only, not metropolitan area) is about 3.1 million, so the murder rate per 100k inhabitants is more or less 0.5. The city of Chicago, with slightly less population (2.7 million) has a murder rate 30 times higher (Crime in Chicago). Ok, maybe not a good example. The city of Berlin, which is slightly bigger than Madrid (3.5 million) has a murder rate 3 times higher than Madrid.

The majority of those homicides, by the way, were due to domestic violence or violence among criminals. Random crimes that escalate to deadly force are so rare that whenever they occur there is public outrage and immediate action by the authorities.

Rates of less serious crimes are also low, and other than burglaries, in clear decline over the last few years. Burglaries have increased but are still very rare, and when they do take place it's usually on homes that have been left empty for some time (weekends/holidays), invasions of occupied homes are extremely rare.

For foreigners / tourists, there is even less risk as most of the crime is concentrated in neighborhoods where the occasional visitor would normally not have any reasons to go. The only exception is petty theft where tourists are especifically targeted. The areas most packed with tourists have bands of pickpockets that use distraction tactics (beware of street shows and roaming beggars) to lift your wallet or other possessions without you noticing. There is also the risk that if you leave some item unattended someone could make a run for it and grab it. And of course there are scammers, but they're generally easy to spot and avoid.

The worst incident involving foreigners in recent memory was some years ago, when a series of violent assaults on Asian tourists took place in downtown Madrid. The culprits were criminals of Moroccan origin who would prey on local Chinese immigrants under the flawed assumption that they would not report such crimes because many were illegal or worked in irregular businesses. Of course, as soon as Chinese and Japanese tourists started being assaulted as well it became a very visible problem and the Spanish government isued a crackdown that pretty much ended that type of crime.

These days the most popular tourist destinations are heavily patrolled by police for security reasons, and of course there's the fact that streets in the center of Madrid are usually packed with people until very late at night. Just keep an eye on your possessions and follow basic precautions and you'll be ok.

Who owns Real Madrid F.C.?

The owner of Real Madrid club is a group of club lovers who are effectively the supporters of the club. The club has a President in the form of Florentino Perez, he is not the owner of the club. Currently, more than 90,000 ‘socios‘ exist and they collectively own the club.

Who founded Madrid?

Madrid, originally called Mayrit, was founded by the emir Muhammad at the end of the IX century. It was under the Arab occupation of the Iberian Peninsula, that the city gained importance, since initially the main city in the Spanish plain had been Toledo.

During the Reconquest of Spain by the Christians, Madrid passed from Muslim to Christian hands several times, it was the origin of the mixture of cultures which characterizes the city still today.

The present location of Madrid, in the centre of Spain, was established by the king Alfonso I in 1083. Under Christian control, all symbols of the Muslim world were removed from the city and part of the cultural heritage of Madrid was lost.

During the following centuries the city developed reaching its current aspect. The Main Square (Plaza Mayor) was built under the auspice of John II on the 13th century. Later on, Enrique III ordered the building of El Pardo Palace as a place of residence for royal visits, the city kept on growing in size, and finally in 1561 the Spanish Court was transferred from its location in Toledo to Madrid. The seat of the Spanish Court moved again to Valladolid in 1601, but it returned definitively to Madrid 5 years later.

The 19th century was a sad time for Madrid with bloody historical events such as the rising of the city against French occupation on May 2nd 1808, and the beginning of the Spanish war of Independence.

In the 20th century after the dead of General Franco, the Spanish Constitution of 1978 confirmed Madrid as capital city of Spain. In 1979, the first democratic local elections were held in Madrid to choose the first city mayor; the first governor of the city was Enrique Tierno Galván.

By this time Madrid had grown in size and population reaching the figure of 3 million inhabitants in the metropolitan area and nearly 6 million people in the whole province of Madrid.

Why is Real Madrid named Real Madrid?

Real Madrid had two major names in their history:

First they were Madrid CF (Madrid Club de Fútbol). This is how most normal teams are named. For most teams in Spain, they just have their name be like this, and nothing changes.

So how do you become "Royal"? (Real). Simple, King Alfonso XIII gave the club "Royal" Status (Madrid Receives the Title of 'Real' (1911-1920) | Real Madrid CF).

King Alfonso XIII

A bunch of other clubs have "Real" in their name:

  • Real Aranjuez CF
  • Real Avila CF

  • Real Jaen

So yeah, there's a lot of clubs, just not FC Barcelona, or some other major teams.

On what basis do the people of Madrid support Real Madrid or Athletico Madrid?

Today, it is mostly a matter of “identity”, which is very influenced by your family (typically your father). Fans tend to support the team their parents supported.

Secondly (and related to the above) is geographic location. AM is more popular in the south and SW of Madrid (where the different stadiums have been located) while RM is more popular in the northern Madrid (where their stadium is located). The north is more affluent.

A very schematic map of Madrid, see RM stadium in the north and AM stadium in the SW:

Today, it is mostly a matter of “identity”, which is very influenced by your family (typically your father). Fans tend to support the team their parents supported.

Secondly (and related to the above) is geographic location. AM is more popular in the south and SW of Madrid (where the different stadiums have been located) while RM is more popular in the northern Madrid (where their stadium is located). The north is more affluent.

A very schematic map of Madrid, see RM stadium in the north and AM stadium in the SW:

Thirdly (also related to the first) is (perceived) social class. AM has traditionally been linked to working classes. It is not necessarily correlated with money. Some sons of working class’ parents perceive themselves as working class, despite making more than other white collar workers. With social mobility (which has been intense in the past 30 years in Spain) this effect is diminished, but not completely annulled. Atlético would be “leftist” and RM “rightist”, which a bit pinch of salt.

Fourth is a matter or values (although this I think is more a consequence rather than a cause). Real Madrid supporters believe they support “the best” team. The team more able to win titles and glory. (“If supporting someone is essentially free, why not support directly the best team around?”) Atlético supporters consider themselves more modest (RM is arrogant by definition), they even pride themselves on supporting the team when they lose. The ironically call their own team “el pupas” (which is a boy that is all the time hurting himself and having bad luck). (RM supporters are ruthless when they lose, they expect excellence at every match). Thus AM consider themselves the best crowd (in terms of unconditional love) while RM fans consider themselves more exigent and “connoisseurs”. Atlético supporters even consider themselves “better people” vs Real Madrid.

These are of course general rules with as many exceptions as there are fans. Most people cannot explain, but in my experience, these would more or less be the drivers.
